user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskDelete_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_TaskDelete_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_task_internal_record_t *impl;
    void *                          retval;
    int                             ret;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_task_table, *token);

    /*
    ** Try to delete the task
    ** If this fails, not much recourse - the only potential cause of failure
    ** to cancel here is that the thread ID is invalid because it already exited itself,
    ** and if that is true there is nothing wrong - everything is OK to continue normally.
    */
    ret = pthread_cancel(impl->id);
    if (ret != 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("pthread_cancel: Failed on Task ID = %lu, err = %s\n",
                 OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), strerror(ret));

        /* fall through (will still return OS_SUCCESS) */
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * Note that "pthread_cancel" is a request - and successful return above
         * only means that the cancellation request is pending.
         *
         * pthread_join() will wait until the thread has actually exited.
         *
         * This is important for CFE, as task deletion often occurs in
         * conjunction with an application reload - which means the next
         * call is likely to be OS_ModuleUnload().  So is critical that all
         * tasks potentially executing code within that module have actually
         * been stopped - not just pending cancellation.
         */
        ret = pthread_join(impl->id, &retval);
        if (ret != 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("pthread_join: Failed on Task ID = %lu, err = %s\n",
                     OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), strerror(ret));
        }
    }
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TaskDelete_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_task_internal_record_t OS_impl_task_table[OS_MAX_TASKS]
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_t id;
} OS_impl_task_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
static inline osal_id_t OS_ObjectIdFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_id;
}
...
static inline unsigned long OS_ObjectIdToInteger(osal_id_t object_id)
{
#ifdef OSAL_OMIT_DEPRECATED
    return object_id.v;
#else
    return object_id;
#endif
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: All other code fragments in the function are straightforward and do not present obvious unreachable-code issues: the local declarations are always reachable; the call to pthread_cancel() and the subsequent conditional on its return value use a non-constant run-time result so both branches can be reached at run time; there are no unconditional returns or infinite loops earlier in the function that would make later statements unreachable. The suspicious fragments listed above are provided for further inspection (they involve macro expansion, conditional fall-through behavior, the pthread_join path, and the function's unconditional return) and should be examined to determine whether any of them can become unreachable in some build/configuration or due to macro definitions.
